It's time for leaders at every level‚Äîlocal, state, and federal‚Äîto stop tiptoeing around the problem and tackle it head-on. Our land is burning, and with it, the dreams of countless families. Topics.title: The toll of the cobalt mining industry on health and the environment
Topics.posting:
According to the CDC, "chronic exposure to cobalt-containing hard metal (dust or fume) can result in a serious lung disease called 'hard metal lung disease'" ‚Äì a kind of pneumoconiosis, meaning a lung disease caused by inhaling dust particles. Inhalation of cobalt particles can cause respiratory sensitization, asthma, decreased pulmonary function and shortness of breath, the CDC says.

The health agency says skin contact is also a significant health concern "because dermal exposures to hard metal and cobalt salts can result in significant systemic uptake." 

"Sustained exposures can cause skin sensitization, which may result in eruptions of contact dermatitis," a red, itchy skin rash, the CDC says.

Despite the health risks, researchers with Amnesty International found that most cobalt miners in Congo lack basic protective equipment like face masks, work clothing and gloves. Many of the miners the organization spoke with for its 2016 report ‚Äì 90 people in total who work, or worked, in the mines ‚Äì complained of frequent coughing or lung problems.
